title: A2 - Past Tense (Perfekt) Quiz
description: Test your understanding of the past tense (Perfekt) in German

questions.feedback: Correct! 'gehen' uses 'sein' as its auxiliary verb in the Perfekt tense.
Correct! 'lesen' is a transitive verb, so it uses 'haben' as its auxiliary verb in the Perfekt tense.
Correct! 'kaufen' is a transitive verb, so it uses 'haben' as its auxiliary verb in the Perfekt tense.
Correct! 'ankommen' is a verb of motion, so it uses 'sein' as its auxiliary verb in the Perfekt tense.
Correct! 'einschlafen' indicates a change of state, so it uses 'sein' as its auxiliary verb in the Perfekt tense.

questions.text: Which of these verbs forms its past participle as 'gegessen'?
questions.feedback: Correct! 'essen' (to eat) forms its past participle as 'gegessen'.

questions.text: What is the past participle of 'sehen'?
questions.feedback: Correct! The past participle of 'sehen' is 'gesehen'.

questions.text: What is the correct past participle of 'aufstehen'?
questions.feedback: Correct! For separable verbs like 'aufstehen', the 'ge-' goes between the prefix and the verb stem, and 'stehen' has the irregular participle 'gestanden', resulting in 'aufgestanden'.

questions.text: What is the past participle of 'verstehen'?
questions.feedback: Correct! Verbs with inseparable prefixes like 'ver-' don't add 'ge-' in the past participle. The participle of 'verstehen' is 'verstanden'.

questions.text: What is the past participle of 'studieren'?
questions.feedback: Correct! Verbs ending in '-ieren' don't add 'ge-' in the past participle. The participle of 'studieren' is simply 'studiert'.
Correct! 'Fahren' is a verb of motion, so it uses 'sein' as its auxiliary verb, and its past participle is 'gefahren'.
Correct! 'Haben' uses 'haben' as its auxiliary verb, and its past participle is 'gehabt'.
Correct! 'Machen' is a regular verb using 'haben', and its past participle is 'gemacht'.

questions.text: Which of these verbs always uses 'sein' in the Perfekt?
questions.feedback: Correct! 'Bleiben' (to stay) always uses 'sein' in the Perfekt tense.
